results.title: The Slender span
results.brief_description: The building of the new 5,240 foot long suspension bridge over the River Severn which is designed to improve communication between England and South Wales. Shows sequences of building which include the construction of the concrete piers and 400 foot towers, the spinning of the main cables and the hoisting of the large roadway sections into position.

results.title: The Sleepwatchers
results.creator_credit: Columbia Broadcasting System, Isaac Kleinerman and James Jackson
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 21st Century”.
Presents a report on current research being done on various aspects of sleep. How much sleep human beings need, what happens to someone deprived of sleep, what sleep is like for the mentally ill, what causes sleepwalking and how to cure it and how much time each night is spent dreaming are among some of the questions dealt with in this film. Reporter: Walter Cronkite.

results.title: The Sleeping tiger
results.brief_description: Directed by Joseph Losey in 1954, “The Sleeping Tiger” was his first feature made in Britain which came to typify what was later referred to as, ‘Losey Baroque’. In this domestic drama, criminal Frank Clements (Dirk Bogarde) becomes a ‘home-trial’ case patient for psychologist, Dr. Clive Esmond (Alexander Knox) and inadvertently his wife, Glenda (Alexis Smith). Forced to undergo psychoanalytic reform in place of a prison sentence, Frank proceeds to provoke emotional conflict in all their relationships. Frank with his excessive passions, and Clive with his emotionally detached approach provide great shadow plays. As Freudian displacement eventuates the themes of disaffection, frustration and alienation spark dramatic changes in all their lives. Dr. Esmond.” In the dark forest of every human personality there is a sleeping tiger.” Who will be freed from their compulsions? Based on the book of the same name by Maurice Moiseiwitsch.

results.title: The Sleeping feel good movie
results.brief_description: Adopts a light-hearted approach to the topic of the body’s need for sleep. The benfits of adequate sleep for children are shown as are the health hazards of insufficient sleep. The abundant energy of the children who enjoy regular sleep is contrasted with humorous pictures of children who are unable to keep their eyes open, due to poor sleeping habits. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Sleeping beauty (Imperial Russian Ballet)
results.creator_credit: Gosteleradio, National Video Corporation (International), Konstantin Sergeyev, Svetlana Kononchuk, Maxim Krastin and Elena Macheret
results.brief_description: The Imperial Russian Ballet at the Maryinsky Theatre in St Petersburg first performed this beautiful classical ballet, choreographed by Marius Petipa to the wonderful score composed by Tchaikovsky, in 1890. In this 1983 television production, tradition is carried on by the world renowned Kirov Ballet at the Leningrad Theatre of Opera and Ballet with principal dancers Irina Kolpakova (Princess Aurora), Sergei Berezhnoi (Prince Desire), Lubov Kunakova (the Lilac Fairy) and Vladimir Lopukhov (Carabosse) presenting a truly glorious performance. Also features the magical music of the Orchestra of the Leningrad Theatre of Opera and Ballet conducted by Viktor Fedotov and choreography by Oleg Vinogradov.

results.title: The Sleeping beauty (Bolshoi Ballet)
results.creator_credit: NHK Entapuraizu, Videofilm, RPTA, Primetime, Takeshi Hara and Shuji Fujii
results.brief_description: The Bolshoi at the Bolshoi presents Tchaikovsky’s “The Sleeping beauty” in three acts with scenario by Ivan Vsevolozhsky and Marius Petipa, based upon the tales of Charles Perrault. Features the Bolshoi Theatre Orchestra conducted by Aleksandr Kopilov and choreography by Marius Petipa staged by Yuri Grigorovich. This beautiful fairytale ballet is performed by dancers Nina Semizorova (Princess Aurora), Aleksei Fadeyecher (Prince Desire), Nina Speranskaya (Lilac Fairy), Yuri Vetrov (Carabosse), Aleksandr Vetrov (Bluebird), and Maria Bilova (Princess Florine).

results.title: The Sleep of reason
results.creator_credit: Mathews Jordan Production, Australian Film Commission, Sue Mathews and Peter Jordan
results.brief_description: The exploding of the atomic bomb over Hiroshima on August 6, 1945 made possible the apocalyptic extermination of the human race. This complex and moving documentary traces the history of human visions of “apocalypse”. Through an exploration of the vast canvases of Heironymous Bosch and Bruegel, the Japanese “monster” movies of the 1950s and the home-movies taken at the Nevada site at Las Alamos where the first nuclear tests were undertaken, “The Sleep of Reason” is an insight into the unconscious fears that underlie religious myths of punishment and redemption. However, the explosion of the bomb over Hiroshima dragged the apocalypse from mythology into reality and since that cataclysmic event, humanity has had to learn to live with the knowledge that it has the power to destroy itself. Filmed in the rebuilt city of Hiroshima, the film interviews philosopher George Steiner, psychoanalyst Robert Lifton, art historian Donald Kuspit and film writer Vivian Sobchack who all offer interpretations on how the bomb has affected global culture. An excerpt from an interview with Robert Oppenheimer, who breaks into tears as he talks about his work on creating the atomic bomb, is also included in this remarkable film.

results.title: The Sky Pirates (Captioned)
results.brief_description: When their model plane crashes at the Aero Club, Mike and Harry are befriended by ex-pilot, Charlie Bradford, and his niece, Maggie, who teach them to fly radio controlled planes. Charlie invites them to the test flight of his new long distance aircraft which is later stolen. When they learn that a diamond has been stolen from the French State Museum, they realise the plane is to be used to smuggle the diamond out of the country.
